translation: So, it wasn't worth it for him to commute frequently for a long distance, it was better for the family to move away.
So, we agreed with the decision and went ahead and moved south to New York; it was around an hour north of NYC.
But, you might wonder how I managed, with moving frequently, well I was home schooled.
so I didn`t need to worry about attending a hearing school or a Deaf school.
My mother taught my two brothers and me, so it was easier for us to move around.
I guess I should`ve been moving away again, but my parents were okay with the same job.
My parents were alright with it. I transferred to RSD, I stayed in the dorm.
When I was nearly all done with RIT. after about my third year. my father sensed that he had pretty much had it with IBM; he wanted to retire and change his career.
I was like, “Oh, wow, that`s fine.” He wanted to transfer to Rochester because he wanted to work at RIT too.
So, the family in fact move here, and I took the opportunity to move in and live with my family at the new house in Rochester.

I graduated recently, so that`s means I`ll be looking for a job, probably I`ll move away, so I won't have lived there for seven years.   Now, I`m wondering from now on with the new job does that mean I might be moving around again for the next seven years or less?   So I`m wondering, let`s see, oh well.
There are so many things that are wrong with the system.
Then they would ask the HIT group about the car and whether if the glass was broken.
Or they will ask another group SMASHED about the car and whether if the glass was broken.
Or ask the COLLIDED group about the car and if the glass was broken?
Ask another group, the CRASHED group about the car and whether if the glass is broken.
The study notices how the HIT group thinks that the glass wasn't broken at all.
The car was going around 20 mph when it smashed. The SMASHED group said they think the car's glass was broken and it was going around 60 mph. But, actually, the glass wasn't broken at all.
That's how powerful the language is.
The first thing the doctor and nurse would say to the parents would be "I am sorry." It's an automatic negative. "I am sorry that your child is Deaf".
Of course the parents would be scared. "I am sorry" is never a good thing.
The meeting will include a specialist, audiologist, doctor, nurse, counselor, and social worker. There are seven specialists for only two parents. Wow.
It is very intimidating. There will be seven professionals informing the two parents that their child seem to be sick or have the "cancer".
They often use the word "diagnosis" It's very negative and it's used for more negative references, such as sickness or cancer. Or maybe terminal illness.
Why don't they use a word like "identified" as in "I've identified this child deaf"? Now it does not seem bad at all.
Now parents often would start considering discussing with the hospital for the early intervention. But the word makes it seems like they are intervening.
"Intervention" implies the need of intervening such as an intervention for drug addicts, stopping something from happening, or when a kid is not behaving well.
It seems like the hospital needed to intervene because the parents were doing lousy job with their child.
The baby is just deaf. It's not their fault, they're doing perfectly fine.
Why don't we use "early involvement", which means involving the parents by sharing the resources and working together; and not intervening them.
That makes it to seem like an opportunity to do more than one.
The parents might will perceive this as something they should to be upset about.
It would turn into a positive thing.
A Deaf role model who has been trained can show the parents that he/she is perfectly fine.
He/she can read and write. He/she can communicate. He/she can work. He/she has an education. There's a long list of that and he/she is perfectly fine.
The researches have proven that a child with a Deaf mentor often perform better. There is a research that studies two groups from Utah and Tennessee.
The study noticed that the Deaf child from Utah resulted in better social, emotion and cognitive developments.
Be friends with their child's friend's parents. It's important to be connected and they must collaborate with others.
When a deaf child does not have a Deaf mentor, the family will continue to be disappointed and their grief will last longer.
So, the family must have a Deaf role model supporting them.

The first topic relates to the voice -the role of the voice in an audio vocal oriented culture, It is very powerful.

If you speak fast it means that you're smart, witty, smooth, and have a sharp mind.
This is connected to the voice itself, and it is displayed like a print within voice identity.
Oftentimes, people who have experience  talking on the phone, visualize what the person they're talking to might look like.
When on the phone the person may perceive who they're talking to as being tall, smart, good looking and nice. They agree to meet the person the next day near the train and hang up
Many people were shocked when they found out that the person and the voice didn't match up, especially John Gilbert, who was one character that was mentioned.
John's voice was a good match to the character he played. His character in the movie was that of a swashbuckler.
People who watch silent films can't hear it but can imagine a strong, heavy baritone voice from that swashbuckler character.
When it was time for his voice test, his voice didn't match the character. Things weren't like they used to be and his career slumped.
The voice is really important because it gives a lot of information about individual people, and that's the focus of cultural orientation.
It's like ventriloquism when they transfer their voice to the puppet.
and even worse, whose is the voice that you're associating with a persona.

I want to share with you the experience that I had growing up.
I had received my report card and in it, it read that I had great deaf speech.

As I looked at my report card, I thought well I'm deaf but that doesn't matter because my report card says good speech. I imagined this meant that my speech was equal to that of a hearing person. Wow, I really had good speech.
That's an accomplishment, I thought. Thank you!
It wasn't until later that I realized that the concept of deaf speech was really important.
It meant that within that category, I was good.
The range goes from "intelligible," meaning it can be understood, to nothing comprehensible, "grunts."

All three of these are characteristics of deaf speech.  All of them are characteristics that hearing people find annoying.

The hearing people don't tell each other, "you have a good speech," they don't.
What they praise is connected to the voice; they say, "you have a beautiful voice"…
i see: They know I'm Deaf and they imagine that Deaf people cannot speak. But then they realize that I can speak, so they offer praise. That praise itself has an underlying meaning, though.

That kind of sound has a different meaning. What happens in situations with grants is that there can be many different cultural situations where there are uncontrollable voices, voice excess or grunts, and it's not acceptable. It really blocks your communication process.

Screaming for example is set up in culture based on a range of what's an acceptable scream. If you go beyond that range, basically, the scream becomes excessive.
He placed third in the election but was willing to give his speech that he prepared to win the Caucus. So as he was presenting his voice was building up and he started screaming.
The presenter's scream was a little bit over the normal range to the point where people were staring and shocked and wanted him to stop.
Once the news got a hold of the scream speech, his career and the possiblility of him becoming president went downhill. It was over from that one scream situation.

People can't imagine how, if a person who can't control his voice, how he would run the country. So automatically people can't accept him as president just by his voice. That is an example of excessive voice in comparison to grunts.

There are many implications associated with deaf experiences and trying to make accommodations. Often people will hear a deaf person and criticize them and think there's something wrong until they find out the person is deaf and then the situation is excused. But there is still that initial rude stare because people aren't making that connection between what they hear and the deaf person.

There's even a specific way to laugh. Laughter has a cultural range already set up and if the laugh goes beyond the acceptable range, people will cover their mouths to try to control or muffle the laugh.

The point is that there is excessive voice and people often comment on how deaf people laugh. They's say "you know deaf people laugh differently" Well what does that mean? Laughing itself is natural. If there's a funny situation you laugh and enjoy laughing, ae you supposed to control it?
Other cultures have controlled laughing. They have their own acceptable range that you shouldn't go beyond. It's good to stay within the range.
So that comment about how deaf people laugh, well laughing can be taught.

A while back there was a teacher who had a class and taught students how to laugh.The name of the book was  "A List of How to Laugh." The book showed real cultrual ideas of appropriate ranges of laughter. This was conntected to vocal usage from speaking to laughter.

He was shocked that he could hear his parents' voice out of all fans in the grandstand
So it was wow. There are places that loud voices are permitted but you have to experiment enough on the voice range itself. Some areas are quiet, oh.
Or if someone goes above the acceptable range, then people will look upon that person negatively.
When I grew up, I always have been informed that if I need to make natural body noise like a fart, burp, etc., the only place that I can do that is in the bathroom.
So I came to view the bathroom as the safe sanctuary for making those kinds of noises.
When I enter there, I should be feeling free.
But it's not true. People are still judging there.
It's still a necessity to control how you emit the waste properly.
There's a cultural range, you cannot go in the bathroom and emit waste loudly. People would be horrified. You have to emit the waste gently.
When they enter the bathroom and are ready to eliminate waste, they will turn on running water or music to cover up and drown out the bathroom noises.
Bill Ennis told a great story about "bubbles".
He was urinating, and he decided to play around and make bubbles on the toilet.
He was making bubbles creatively. After that, he flushed.
He went out of the bathroom, and he saw his mother looked so horrified as she was on the phone. He asked her, "What's wrong?" She said, "Oh, you made terrible noises."  He was surprised about it.

She said, "You peed on the water, don't do that. You should pee on the bowl of the toilet and avoid water to make it less loud." He learned from his mother that peeing on the water makes a terrible noise.
He was around 15 years old at that time. When he found out, he was disturbed about it. Well, he was lucky, because I know others who didn't come to know about this until much later.
There's a story about a Deaf man who grew up in a hearing family; and the family was not so great with sign language. Every time he went to the bathroom, his parents would react to the loud noise.
His parents tried to tell him to stop. When he came out of the bathroom, his parents would say, "You piss like a horse."
He wasn't sure what was it meant. He thought that it was a positive thing - that he urinated like a very healthy horse. So he was delighted by his parents' comment.
He grew up, he entered college, and he met a hearing CODA woman. He started to like her, and he was around his early to mid 20's at that time.

He said, "Oh really, what is it?" She said, "you urinated on the toilet water, and you should switch to the surface bowl of the toilet to avoid noise." He was embarrassed from girlfriend during that time.
He was very embarrassed.  He realized that he wasn't clear on his parents' remarks when he was growing up. He gulped hard. He changed his habits to urinate on the side of the bowl.
He married that woman and lived happily ever after.
So, I was thinking about this.  Is the bathroom itself a safe sanucatory?  Not necessarily, because hearing people who enter the bathroom can still hear people nearby.
If someone were to make a loud noise, they would be looked down upon as no good, having no class, and being impolite.
My hearing colleague here at Gallaudet University. He told me that he could identify which Deaf or hearing person in the public bathroom as they're in the stall based on how they emit the waste.
Hearing people control the noise when emitting waste, whereas Deaf people emit waste loudly. I was like, "Ohh."
What does it mean if a person emits waste loudly?  There is actually a long list of cultural items that are related to the control of sound.

If a person emits waste loudly, without controlling the noise, it shows the person isn't polite. There is a long list of implicit cultural rules that apply to the Deaf, when they, obliviously, enter the bathroom.

The previous issue in DESDJ volume one number one, focused on visual feeling specifically the tactile orientation.
However, more importantly, they also live in a different sensory world.
Now I would like to focus on audio vocal orientation. They are based on how the specfifc culture...
Most of it is focused on American culture and how people interpret or give meaning to different noises and voices.
The testimonies as well. It's becoming to be like a bricolage, but we collect and organize the deaf experiences instead.
But, for the purpose of this, I would like to focus on two things.
We will expand on the voice and control of sounds in connection with the experiences.
